info.title: ietf-network
info.description:
This module defines a common base data model for a collection
of nodes in a network.  Node definitions are further used
in network topologies and inventories.
Copyright (c) 2018 IETF Trust and the persons identified as
authors of the code.  All rights reserved.
Redistribution and use in source and binary forms, with or
without modification, is permitted pursuant to, and subject
to the license terms contained in, the Simplified BSD License
set forth in Section 4.c of the IETF Trust's Legal Provisions
Relating to IETF Documents
(https://trustee.ietf.org/license-info).
This version of this YANG module is part of RFC 8345;
see the RFC itself for full legal notices.

get.summary:
This list identifies any termination points on which a
given termination point depends or onto which it maps.
Those termination points will themselves be contained
in a supporting node.  This dependency information can be
inferred from the dependencies between links.  Therefore,
this item is not separately configurable.  Hence, no
corresponding constraint needs to be articulated.
The corresponding information is simply provided by the
implementing system.

get.summary:
Name of the interface.  The name can (but does not
have to) correspond to an interface reference of a
containing node's interface, i.e., the path name of a
corresponding interface data node on the containing
node reminiscent of data type interface-ref defined
in RFC 8343. It should be noted that data type
interface-ref of RFC 8343 cannot be used directly,
as this data type is used to reference an interface
in a datastore of a single node in the network, not
to uniquely reference interfaces across a network.

get.summary:
A network link connects a local (source) node and
a remote (destination) node via a set of the respective
node's termination points.  It is possible to have several
links between the same source and destination nodes.
Likewise, a link could potentially be re-homed between
termination points.  Therefore, in order to ensure that we
would always know to distinguish between links, every link
is identified by a dedicated link identifier.  Note that a
link models a point-to-point link, not a multipoint link.

data-post.description:
This module defines a common base data model for a collection
of nodes in a network.  Node definitions are further used
in network topologies and inventories.

ietf-restconf:restconf.description: This is the RESTCONF root resource for the RESTCONF datastore and operation resources. See RESTCONF RFC 8040 for further information.

ietf-restconf:operations.description: This resource is a container that provides access to the data-model-specific RPC operations supported by the server. See RESTCONF RFC 8040 for further information.

ietf-network:supporting-network.description:
An underlay network, used to represent layered network
topologies. (list)

ietf-network:network-ref.description:
References the underlay network of which the
underlay node is a part. (leaf)

ietf-network:supporting-node.description:
Represents another node that is in an underlay network
and that supports this node.  Used to represent layering
structure. (list)

network-ref.description:
References the underlay network of which the
underlay node is a part. (leaf)

ietf-network:node-id.description:
Uniquely identifies a node within the containing
network. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:tp-ref.description:
Reference to the underlay node (the underlay node must
be in a different topology). (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:node-ref.description:
This leaf identifies in which node the supporting
termination point is present. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:network-ref.description:
This leaf identifies in which topology the
supporting termination point is present. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:supporting-termina.description:
This list identifies any termination points on which a
given termination point depends or onto which it maps.
Those termination points will themselves be contained
in a supporting node.  This dependency information can be
inferred from the dependencies between links.  Therefore,
this item is not separately configurable.  Hence, no
corresponding constraint needs to be articulated.
The corresponding information is simply provided by the
implementing system. (list)

ietf-network-topology:network-ref.description:
This leaf identifies in which topology the
supporting termination point is present. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:node-ref.description:
This leaf identifies in which node the supporting
termination point is present. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:tp-ref.description:
Reference to the underlay node (the underlay node must
be in a different topology). (leaf)

ietf-l3-unicast-topology:unnumbered-id.description:
Unnumbered interface identifier.
The identifier will correspond to the ifIndex value
of the interface, i.e., the ifIndex value of the
ifEntry that represents the interface in
implementations where the Interfaces Group MIB
(RFC 2863) is supported. (leaf)

ietf-l3-unicast-topology:interface-name.description:
Name of the interface.  The name can (but does not
have to) correspond to an interface reference of a
containing node's interface, i.e., the path name of a
corresponding interface data node on the containing
node reminiscent of data type interface-ref defined
in RFC 8343. It should be noted that data type
interface-ref of RFC 8343 cannot be used directly,
as this data type is used to reference an interface
in a datastore of a single node in the network, not
to uniquely reference interfaces across a network. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:termination-point.description:
A termination point can terminate a link.
Depending on the type of topology, a termination point
could, for example, refer to a port or an interface. (list)

ietf-network-topology:supporting-termina.description:
This list identifies any termination points on which a
given termination point depends or onto which it maps.
Those termination points will themselves be contained
in a supporting node.  This dependency information can be
inferred from the dependencies between links.  Therefore,
this item is not separately configurable.  Hence, no
corresponding constraint needs to be articulated.
The corresponding information is simply provided by the
implementing system. (list)

could, for example, refer to a port or an interface. (list)

ietf-network-topology:supporting-termina.description:
This list identifies any termination points on which a
given termination point depends or onto which it maps.
Those termination points will themselves be contained
in a supporting node.  This dependency information can be
inferred from the dependencies between links.  Therefore,
this item is not separately configurable.  Hence, no
corresponding constraint needs to be articulated.
The corresponding information is simply provided by the
implementing system. (list)

ietf-network-topology:link.description:
A network link connects a local (source) node and
a remote (destination) node via a set of the respective
node's termination points.  It is possible to have several
links between the same source and destination nodes.
Likewise, a link could potentially be re-homed between
termination points.  Therefore, in order to ensure that we
would always know to distinguish between links, every link
is identified by a dedicated link identifier.  Note that a
link models a point-to-point link, not a multipoint link. (list)

ietf-network-topology:link-id.description:
The identifier of a link in the topology.
A link is specific to a topology to which it belongs. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:source.description:
This container holds the logical source of a particular
link. (non-presence)

and terminates the link. (leaf)

This container holds the logical destination of a
particular link. (non-presence)

Destination node identifier.  Must be in the same
network. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:dest-tp.description:

network-topology data model), and layering information. (list)

network-types.description:
Serves as an augmentation target.
The network type is indicated through corresponding
presence containers augmented into this container. (non-presence)

ietf-l3-unicast-topology:l3-unicast-topo.description:
The presence of the container node indicates L3 Unicast
topology (presence)

ietf-sr-topology:sr-mpls.description: Its presence identifies the SR topology type. (presence)

supporting-network.description:
An underlay network, used to represent layered network
topologies. (list)

node.description: The inventory of nodes of this network. (list)

node-id.description:
Uniquely identifies a node within the containing
network. (leaf)

supporting-node.description:
Represents another node that is in an underlay network
and that supports this node.  Used to represent layering
structure. (list)

network-ref.description:
References the underlay network of which the
underlay node is a part. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:termination-point.description:
A termination point can terminate a link.
Depending on the type of topology, a termination point
could, for example, refer to a port or an interface. (list)

ietf-network-topology:supporting-termina.description:
This list identifies any termination points on which a
given termination point depends or onto which it maps.
Those termination points will themselves be contained
in a supporting node.  This dependency information can be
inferred from the dependencies between links.  Therefore,
this item is not separately configurable.  Hence, no
corresponding constraint needs to be articulated.
The corresponding information is simply provided by the
implementing system. (list)

ietf-network-topology:network-ref.description:
This leaf identifies in which topology the
supporting termination point is present. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:node-ref.description:
This leaf identifies in which node the supporting
termination point is present. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:tp-ref.description:
Reference to the underlay node (the underlay node must
be in a different topology). (leaf)

ietf-l3-unicast-topology:prefix.description: A list of prefixes along with their attributes (list)

ietf-sr-topology:sr.description: Containing SR attributes for a prefix. (presence)

ietf-sr-topology:value-type.description: This leaf defines how value must be interpreted. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:start-sid.description:
Value associated with prefix. The value must be
interpreted in the context of value-type. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:range.description: Indicates how many SIDs can be allocated. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:is-node.description:
'true' if the Prefix-SID refers to the router identified
 by the prefix.  Typically, the leaf 'is-node' (N-Flag)
 is set on Prefix-SIDs attached to a router loopback
 address. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:is-readvertisment.description:
'true' if the prefix to which this Prefix-SID is attached,
 has been propagated by the router from another
 topology by redistribution. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:srgb.description: List of global blocks to be advertised. (list)

ietf-sr-topology:lower-bound.description: Lower value in the label range. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:upper-bound.description: Upper value in the label range. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:lower-bound.description: Lower value in the label range. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:upper-bound.description: Upper value in the label range. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:node-capabilities.description: Shows the SR capability of the node. (non-presence)

ietf-sr-topology:entropy-readable-label-.description: Maximum label stack depth that a router can read. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:msd.description: Node MSD is the lowest MSD supported by the node. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:information-source.description: Indicates the type of the information source. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:information-source-inst.description:
The name indicating the instance of the information
source. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:information-source-stat.description:
The container contains state attributes related to
the information source. (non-presence)

ietf-sr-topology:credibility-preference.description:
The preference value to calculate the traffic
engineering database credibility value used for
tie-break selection between different
information-source values.
Higher value is more preferable. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:link.description:
A network link connects a local (source) node and
a remote (destination) node via a set of the respective
node's termination points.  It is possible to have several
links between the same source and destination nodes.
Likewise, a link could potentially be re-homed between
termination points.  Therefore, in order to ensure that we
would always know to distinguish between links, every link
is identified by a dedicated link identifier.  Note that a
link models a point-to-point link, not a multipoint link. (list)

ietf-network-topology:link-id.description:
The identifier of a link in the topology.
A link is specific to a topology to which it belongs. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:source.description:
This container holds the logical source of a particular
link. (non-presence)

ietf-network-topology:source-node.description: Source node identifier.  Must be in the same topology. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:source-tp.description:
This termination point is located within the source node
and terminates the link. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:destination.description:
This container holds the logical destination of a
particular link. (non-presence)

ietf-network-topology:dest-node.description:
Destination node identifier.  Must be in the same
network. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:dest-tp.description:
This termination point is located within the
destination node and terminates the link. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:supporting-link.description: Identifies the link or links on which this link depends. (list)

ietf-network-topology:network-ref.description:
This leaf identifies in which underlay topology
the supporting link is present. (leaf)

ietf-network-topology:link-ref.description:
This leaf identifies a link that is a part
of this link's underlay.  Reference loops in which
a link identifies itself as its underlay, either
directly or transitively, are not allowed. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:value-type.description: This leaf defines how value must be interpreted. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:sid.description:
Adjacency SID, which can be either IGP-Adjacency SID
or BGP PeerAdj SID, depending on the context. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:advertise-protection.description:
If set, the Adj-SID refers to an
adjacency being protected. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:msd.description: SID depth of the interface associated with the link. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:address-family.description:
This leaf defines the F-Flag (Address-Family flag) of the
SID. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:is-backup.description: 'true' if the SID is a backup. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:is-part-of-set.description: 'true' if the SID is part of a set. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:is-persistent.description: 'true' if the SID is persistently allocated. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:information-source.description: Indicates the type of the information source. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:information-source-inst.description:
The name indicating the instance of the information
source. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:information-source-stat.description:
The container contains state attributes related to
the information source. (non-presence)

ietf-sr-topology:credibility-preference.description:
The preference value to calculate the traffic
engineering database credibility value used for
tie-break selection between different
information-source values.
Higher value is more preferable. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:srgb.description: List of global blocks to be advertised. (list)

ietf-sr-topology:lower-bound.description: Lower value in the label range. (leaf)

ietf-sr-topology:upper-bound.description: Upper value in the label range. (leaf)

ietf-network:networks.description: Serves as a top-level container for a list of networks. (non-presence)

ietf-restconf:data.description: This resource represents the combined configuration and state data resources that can be accessed by a client and cannot be created or deleted by the client. See RESTCONF RFC 8040 for further information.
